Try.definition: to examine or investigate judicially [no fact tried by a jury
Try.origin: [Anglo-French trier to choose, sort, ascertain, examine judicially, from Old French, to choose, sort]

try·ing.definition: [Anglo-Frenchto choose, sort, ascertain, examine judicially, from Old French, to choose, sort]

1.definition: to examine or investigate judicially [no factby a jury, shall be otherwise reexamined in any court of the United States, than according to the rules of the common law "amend. VII"] [in all actionsupon the facts without a jury "Rule 52(a)"]
1.tried: upon the facts without a jury "

2.definition: to conduct the trial ofput on trial [if…the judge before whom the defendant has beenis unable to perform the duties to be performed by the court after a verdict or finding of guilt "Rule 25(b)"]
2.tried: is unable to perform the duties to be performed by the court after a verdict or finding of guilt "

3.definition: to participate as lawyer or counsel in the trial ofbring to trial on behalf of a client [was unqualified to death penalty cases]
